answers.answer: Yes, they could all be easily be related to diabetes.  Sometimes the numbers can change when your glucose levels improve also.  Make sure you are seeing an ophthalmologist and you may need an endocrinologist as well.  Pregnancy can also cause wide changes in refraction especially when combined with diabetes.  This is related to swelling of the lens and some changes in corneal shape.Michael Kutryb, MDKutryb Eye InstituteTitusville, FL

question: I have been wearing glasses for being near sited since 3rd grade.  Since I began wearing contacts I can count on a yearly increase (decrease I guess actually) in my contact perscription of about a 1/4 of a point.  IE -5.5 to -5.75.When I was pregnant it jumped an entire point... I heard this was common.  I also had gestational diabetes.Recently my vision suddenly changed and I couldn't see very well out of my contacts.  I had an exam and found it jumped from -6 to -7... another whole point.  I was diagnosed with diabetes a few weeks later.I have also been noticing tired eyes and more floaters.  Are these things related to my diabetes or just coincidence?
title: drastic vision changes
